title: Leon Greene
text:
Lenard George Green (15 July 1931 – 19 June 2021), better known as Leon Greene, was an English actor and singer.
At the age of 20, Greene joined the <a href="D%27Oyly%20Carte%20Opera%20Company">D'Oyly Carte Opera Company</a> and sang bass with them for just over a year. After leaving the D'Oyly Carte, he appeared in bass roles for several productions between 1954 and 1963 with the <a href="Sadler%27s%20Wells%20Opera">Sadler's Wells Opera</a>. 
In 1963, he moved on to musical comedy, appearing in the <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> production of "<a href="A%20Funny%20Thing%20Happened%20on%20the%20Way%20to%20the%20Forum">A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum</a>" as the Roman captain <a href="Miles%20Gloriosus">Miles Gloriosus</a>. As a result of that performance, he was asked to reprise the role for the film version of the show to begin his career in films.
Among operatic roles were, at Sadler's Wells, one of the three Vagabonds in "<a href="Die%20Kluge">Die Kluge</a>" in 1959, roles in "<a href="The%20Nightingale%20%28opera%29">The Nightingale</a>" and Long Tom in "<a href="Merrie%20England%20%28opera%29">Merrie England</a>" in 1960, Zuniga in "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>" in 1961, Private Willis in "<a href="Iolanthe">Iolanthe</a>" in 1962 (also recorded), Alaska Wolf Joe in "<a href="The%20Rise%20and%20Fall%20of%20the%20City%20of%20Mahagonny">The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny</a>" in 1963, The Cook in "<a href="Love%20for%20Three%20Oranges">Love for Three Oranges</a>" in 1963 (New Opera Company). He sang Lilaque le Fils in "<a href="Boulevard%20Solitude">Boulevard Solitude</a>" in a <a href="New%20Opera%20Company">New Opera Company</a> production at Sadler's Wells in 1963.
Greene's portrayal of in a <a href="Half%20Moon%20Theatre">Half Moon Theatre</a> production in 1985 was described as "the best, grisliest version" in relation to later productions. He reprised Miles Gloriosus in "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" at <a href="Chichester%20Festival%20Theatre">Chichester Festival Theatre</a> in the summer of 1986, and the Baron for <a href="Scottish%20Opera">Scottish Opera</a> and in the award-winning production of "<a href="Candide%20%28operetta%29">Candide</a>" at the <a href="Old%20Vic%20Theatre">Old Vic</a> in 1988-89.
In 1958 he was listed as the Publicity Manager of the London Opera Group, a professional touring opera company directed by Peter Glossop, also singing the title role in "<a href="Don%20Pasquale">Don Pasquale</a>".
His films included "<a href="A%20Funny%20Thing%20Happened%20on%20the%20Way%20to%20the%20Forum%20%28film%29">A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum</a>" (1966), "<a href="A%20Challenge%20for%20Robin%20Hood">A Challenge for Robin Hood</a>" (1967), "<a href="The%20Devil%20Rides%20Out%20%28film%29">The Devil Rides Out</a>" (1968), "<a href="The%20Squeeze%20%281977%20film%29">The Squeeze</a>" (1977), "<a href="Flash%20Gordon%20%28film%29">Flash Gordon</a>" (1980), and several "<a href="Carry%20On%20films">Carry On</a>" comedies.
Greene died in June 2021 at the age of 89.
